thread.title: Online abuse by 'Labour' trolls will only help the Tories

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Online abuse by 'Labour' trolls will only help the Tories
text:
News opinion Online abuse by 'Labour' trolls will only help the Tories Theresa May condemned abuse aimed at Diane Abbott, but she may have had an ulterior motive Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Theresa May devoted part of her conference speech to attacking the vile abuse aimed at Diane Abbott, Labour’s Shadow Home Secretary.
If you discuss politics on social media such as Twitter or Facebook, you’ll soon learn there are some pretty nasty people out there.
Or, at least, they’re nasty when they’re sat in front of their computers or typing words into a phone. Who knows how they’d behave if you met them in person.
But the level of unpleasantness on social media is remarkable.
And Ms Abbott got more abuse on Twitter than any other politician a the last election, according to a study by Amnesty International. Read More Conservatives can win if they explain how they will make life better after Brexit
Some of it was racist and some of it was misogynistic. And perhaps she’s such a target because she’s the most well-known black woman in politics.
Mrs May was clearly right to express solidarity with Ms Abbott and to condemn people who send her abuse.
But she may have had an ulterior motive.
Because there’s a perception that the Labour Party has a particular problem with supporters who behave in a vile way - and that Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has been slow to respond. British Prime Minister Theresa May sits in the audience during the annual Conservative Party Conference (Image: Getty Images Europe)
If the Conservative leader takes the moral high ground on the issue, it looks even worse if Labour appears to be failing to do the same.
The people sending racist abuse to Ms Abbott are unlikely to have been Labour supporters.
But neither did they identify themselves as Tories.
By contrast, you do find people on social media who are unpleasant and claim, at least, to be supporter of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.
For example, they may use the hashtag #jc4pm, which means Jeremy Corbyn for Prime Minister, or use Mr Corbyn’s face as their own personal photo.
That doesn’t happen with Theresa May. Even if they support her, people on the internet don’t tend to use her photo all the time, or add “#tm4pm” to their posts. Read More See Ian Lavery mock Theresa May's dancing to Abba with moves of his own
Conservative MPs are sometimes abused by people who claim to support Jeremy Corbyn. But so are Labour MPs deemed to be disloyal to their leader, along with journalists who have dared to report something that paints him in an unfavourable light.
BBC journalist Laura Kuenssberg is a particular target.
Some Labour politicians fear “left-wing” trolls are damaging their party. And some have even suggested that Labour’s opponents are making fake accounts pretending to support Jeremy Corbyn, just so they can be abusive.
Whatever’s going on, it’s not helpful to Labour.
Mrs May’s comments were clearly right, but they were also smart politics. Like us on Facebook
